pages.text: I have seen that the "sustainable" path forward causes the climate chaos I was trying to avoid. It seems impossible to do something ethical. Every choice I make has some unintended negative consequences. I feel hopeless that the world can even be saved with humanity still here. We are poisonous, a parasite that consumes every part of its host until it is too weak to support the parasite,

killing it along with all of the remaining life. $(br2)The urge to grow, to continue to improve my efficiency and to explore new technology followed me here even when I made such an effort to lead a simple life. Is it human nature to seek more, to never be satisfied with life in the present? Is greed a part of the human condition, and if so, is it a natural consequence that the world has to rid itself of our species eventually?

With this new hopelessness, my mind becomes less burdened with guilt. If the calamities caused by the wealthy a thousand years ago, and the similar problems that are starting to arise now are destiny, what is the point in trying to save the world, to try to be better? $(br2)I have hit a wall with my industrial agricultural practices that can't be overcome without investing in more advanced technology, and with the weight of being
personally responsible for the end of the world off of my shoulders, I should push forward.
